abstracts.cdata!:
The Economic Recovery Support Operation
            Project for Dominica had the following ratings: the outcome
            was satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was substantial, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory. The
            lessons learned indicate that the decision to do a single
            tranche operation was adequate in view of the Government
            strategy to pursue a two stage approach designed to, first,
            achieve stabilization of the country's finances and
            initiate key reforms to encourage a resumption of growth
            while, second, identifying and implementing a comprehensive
            medium-term program of reforms to restore growth and
            competitiveness. The successful implementation of the
            Government's program followed from its strong ownership
            and commendable degree of commitment. The very binding
            capacity constraints, arising in significant part from the
            inherent diseconomies of scale involved in a small island
            public sector, have required the judicious selection of
            measures to those that are likely to make the greatest
            impact and are critical to the successful achievement of the
            program objectives. The complexity of the project placed
            great pressure on economic managers and showed the need for
            flexibility on the part of lead donors such as the Bank and
            Fund. Close coordination among donors in the provision of
            financial and technical assistance greatly contributed to
            the outcome of the reform program.
